title: Learning Models, Supermodels, and Ensemble Models of Dynamic Systems

Now the typical machine learning approach to learning all sorts of models, not necessarily just ordinary differential equations, is to actually search a space of possible model structures.
So both structures and parameters and the questions that appear in this context are what is this space?
So what kind of structures do we consider that we consider polynomial?
Do we consider some nonlinear types of structures and the second major question is, what is the heuristic that moves us through this space that?
That's the search and typically this is when we when we learn equations of different source.
This is the error or degree of fit of the model to the data, but additional factors such as model complexity can be taken into account.
Now, since we're looking for equations besides the model structure, we really need to take care also of the parameters and.
These are estimated using parameter estimation methods.

A local or derivative based methods such as gradient descent methods, actually quite fast, but they have the problem of getting stuck in local Optima, so we need to look at other parameter estimations which are global such as meta.

Heuristic approach is very well known representative of this is differential evolution, but there is a wide variety of methods such as Ant colony optimization, covariance matrix adaptations and so on and so forth.
The interesting thing about this metaheuristic approaches to parameter estimation, is that they can use different cost functions.
So unlike linear regression, which actually is quite often used to estimate parameters, if the model is linear in the in the parameters.
These and the gradient descent methods typically work with with errors like this.
The metaheuristic approaches can actually use almost arbitrary cost functions.
And the final issue to address in this context is the search strategies.
How we actually search the space, and this can be exhaustive search where we really enumerate and check all of the model structures.
But we can also have heuristic search which is which can be greedy and so we only consider one model structure at a time and then we move from one model structure to another.
Or it can actually be more advanced.
It can be beam search or it can be actually a star search.

So in the field of artificial intelligence, there are many different search methods that have been considered and machine learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence and actually makes extensive use of these search methods developed within its mother area.

No one of the distinguishing characteristics of the approaches to learning models of dynamic systems that we have developed in Uganda is that we do not use only data in learning these models, but we try to take as much as possible into account domain knowledge in the area about the system that we try to model so we can use different types of domain knowledge.
For example, we can use some knowledge about the basic processes that might happen in the that might take place in the domain that we're trying to model.
Which are then treated as building blocks from which we can compose a larger models.
We can take an existing model about the system, but which doesn't really fit the observed data well.
And then we want to modify this model and adapt it to fit the data better.
Or we can have an incompletely specified model which is incomplete to the extent that we cannot even simulate it, but parts of the structure of this model are given.
So these three types of domain knowledge get different names and the corresponding tasks as well.
So when we have an incompletely specified model to begin with, we're talking about model completion.

When we have a complete model, which however is not working very well and we want to revise it, we're talking about model revision, and if we have the basic processes that building blocks, we're talking about inductive process modeling, and this is the.
This is the task that I will actually be discussing in more detail.
In a few minutes now, what is important about these approaches of ours is that they integrate two major modeling approaches.

The first approach is the so called theoretical or knowledge driven modeling approach, where a domain expert that knows the system very well sits down and provides a proper model structure based on his knowledge.
Essentially, he sits down and writes the equations based on his knowledge, possibly leaving the constant parameters to be fitted, but.

The model structure is by and large derived from the knowledge of the expert at the other end of the spectrum we have empirical or data driven modeling, which is a lot based on trial and error where we try different model structures to fit the observed data, and we don't necessarily have a lot of domain knowledge.
So for the theoretical approach we actually do need quite a lot of knowledge about the system that we try to model.
And in the second approach in the empirical modeling approach, we need actually many data of good quality, because otherwise we don't have the hope of deriving reasonable model out of the data.
The advantage of our approaches is that they actually integrate these two approaches, so both the theoretical or knowledge driven and the empirical or data driven approach.
And in this way allow for extra flexibility and in a certain way we can trade off between data and knowledge.
So if we have.
A moderate amount of knowledge but not complete knowledge, and the moderate amount of data but not exhaustive.
We can still derive models of reasonable or reasonable quality.

As we know them in machine learning here, the idea is to learn not just one model, but a set of models which are diverse in the sense that they make different errors on the data, and the idea is that these errors compensate.

Is so called Bootstrap bootstrap sampling.
This is sampling with replacement.
So if we have here 100 data points, we sample 100 data points with replacement.

And this is not an exact copy of the initial set because some of the examples will be sampled more than once, and some of the examples will not appear in the in the sample, and typically a number of such bootstrap replicates is drawn from the training set, and then a learning algorithm is applied to each of these and then finally models are learned.

Now when we want to do Bootstrap sampling from from time series, this is not exactly the same as taking a stationary data set which doesn't depend on time, because when we give the time points to the training algorithm, they need to be with the appropriate order and timestamp.
So what we do is actually we associate await with each example and if the example or data point or some point has not been sampled it gets a weight of 0.

Now the typical machine learning approach to learning all sorts of models, not necessarily just ordinary differential equations, is to actually search a space of possible model structures.
So both structures and parameters and the questions that appear in this context are what is this space?
So what kind of structures do we consider that we consider polynomial?
Do we consider some nonlinear types of structures and the second major question is, what is the heuristic that moves us through this space that?
That's the search and typically this is when we when we learn equations of different source.
This is the error or degree of fit of the model to the data, but additional factors such as model complexity can be taken into account.
Now, since we're looking for equations besides the model structure, we really need to take care also of the parameters and.
These are estimated using parameter estimation methods.

A local or derivative based methods such as gradient descent methods, actually quite fast, but they have the problem of getting stuck in local Optima, so we need to look at other parameter estimations which are global such as meta.

Heuristic approach is very well known representative of this is differential evolution, but there is a wide variety of methods such as Ant colony optimization, covariance matrix adaptations and so on and so forth.
The interesting thing about this metaheuristic approaches to parameter estimation, is that they can use different cost functions.
So unlike linear regression, which actually is quite often used to estimate parameters, if the model is linear in the in the parameters.
These and the gradient descent methods typically work with with errors like this.
The metaheuristic approaches can actually use almost arbitrary cost functions.
And the final issue to address in this context is the search strategies.
How we actually search the space, and this can be exhaustive search where we really enumerate and check all of the model structures.
But we can also have heuristic search which is which can be greedy and so we only consider one model structure at a time and then we move from one model structure to another.
Or it can actually be more advanced.
It can be beam search or it can be actually a star search.

So in the field of artificial intelligence, there are many different search methods that have been considered and machine learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence and actually makes extensive use of these search methods developed within its mother area.

No one of the distinguishing characteristics of the approaches to learning models of dynamic systems that we have developed in Uganda is that we do not use only data in learning these models, but we try to take as much as possible into account domain knowledge in the area about the system that we try to model so we can use different types of domain knowledge.
For example, we can use some knowledge about the basic processes that might happen in the that might take place in the domain that we're trying to model.
Which are then treated as building blocks from which we can compose a larger models.
We can take an existing model about the system, but which doesn't really fit the observed data well.
And then we want to modify this model and adapt it to fit the data better.
Or we can have an incompletely specified model which is incomplete to the extent that we cannot even simulate it, but parts of the structure of this model are given.
So these three types of domain knowledge get different names and the corresponding tasks as well.
So when we have an incompletely specified model to begin with, we're talking about model completion.

When we have a complete model, which however is not working very well and we want to revise it, we're talking about model revision, and if we have the basic processes that building blocks, we're talking about inductive process modeling, and this is the.
This is the task that I will actually be discussing in more detail.
In a few minutes now, what is important about these approaches of ours is that they integrate two major modeling approaches.

The first approach is the so called theoretical or knowledge driven modeling approach, where a domain expert that knows the system very well sits down and provides a proper model structure based on his knowledge.
Essentially, he sits down and writes the equations based on his knowledge, possibly leaving the constant parameters to be fitted, but.

The model structure is by and large derived from the knowledge of the expert at the other end of the spectrum we have empirical or data driven modeling, which is a lot based on trial and error where we try different model structures to fit the observed data, and we don't necessarily have a lot of domain knowledge.
So for the theoretical approach we actually do need quite a lot of knowledge about the system that we try to model.
And in the second approach in the empirical modeling approach, we need actually many data of good quality, because otherwise we don't have the hope of deriving reasonable model out of the data.
The advantage of our approaches is that they actually integrate these two approaches, so both the theoretical or knowledge driven and the empirical or data driven approach.
And in this way allow for extra flexibility and in a certain way we can trade off between data and knowledge.
So if we have.
A moderate amount of knowledge but not complete knowledge, and the moderate amount of data but not exhaustive.
We can still derive models of reasonable or reasonable quality.

As we know them in machine learning here, the idea is to learn not just one model, but a set of models which are diverse in the sense that they make different errors on the data, and the idea is that these errors compensate.
Now most typically this is done by constructing different versions of the training data and then learning a model on each of them.

We then combined the models, or more precisely, their predictions when we need to make a new prediction, and typically simple averaging uses used even though one can learn the combination functions, there is a type of so called meta learning which is called stacking where you really also need to learn the combining function.

Is so called Bootstrap bootstrap sampling.
This is sampling with replacement.
So if we have here 100 data points, we sample 100 data points with replacement.

And this is not an exact copy of the initial set because some of the examples will be sampled more than once, and some of the examples will not appear in the in the sample, and typically a number of such bootstrap replicates is drawn from the training set, and then a learning algorithm is applied to each of these and then finally models are learned.

Now when we want to do Bootstrap sampling from from time series, this is not exactly the same as taking a stationary data set which doesn't depend on time, because when we give the time points to the training algorithm, they need to be with the appropriate order and timestamp.
So what we do is actually we associate await with each example and if the example or data point or some point has not been sampled it gets a weight of 0.
If it has been sampled twice or three times, it gets away for free and then this is taken account into account in the error function.
When we calculate the mean squared errors.
So the errors which are not in the example do not contribute, and those that are in the sample three times or five times contribute as many times to the sum of squared errors.
